sols_html:
We can rewrite the differential equation as

\[\begin{aligned} \displaystyle y'' = -4y = -2^2 \cdot y\end{aligned}\]

Since

\[\begin{aligned} \frac{d^2}{dx^2} \sin(\omega x) = -\omega^2\sin(x)\end{aligned}\]

and

\[\begin{aligned} \frac{d^2}{dx^2} \cos(\omega x) = -\omega^2\cos(x)\end{aligned}\]

we see that \(\displaystyle \sin(\omega x)\) and \(\displaystyle \cos(\omega x)\) are solutions to the equation, with \(\displaystyle \omega = 2\). The solution of the equation must also satisfy the initial condition \(\displaystyle y(0)=1\), which is only the case for \(\displaystyle y = \cos(2x)\). Hence the solution is \(\displaystyle {\color{blue} y =\cos(2x)}\).
